Cairo.description: Cairo is a 2D graphics library. http://cairographics.org/

Image.description:
The Image object can read and draw images and provide the image data as a buffer. Example use: 
	
image = Image clone open("curly.png")
image draw
image scaleTo(image width / 2, image height / 2)
image save("curly.tiff")
When loading an attempt will be made to convert the image into whichever of the following formats it is closest to: L8, LA8, RGB8, RGBA8.

Currently supported formats include PNG(which supports alpha), JPG and TIFF.

slots.filterKirsch(a):
Returns new image as a result of applying Kirsch filter.
	The argument denotes direction: 0, 1, 2, ... -> 0, pi / 4, pi / 2, ...
slots.filterUniformAverage(filterSizeX, filter: Returns new image as a result of applying filter. Implements low pass filtering.
slots.makeGrayscale: Converts color model to Luminance or Luminance-Alpha 8bit (grayscale). Returns self.
slots.averageColor: Returns the average RGB color of all pixels in the image.
slots.filterSobel(a):
Returns new image as a result of applying Sobel filter.
	The argument denotes direction: 0, 1, 2, ... -> 0, pi / 4, pi / 2, ...
slots.setEncodingQuality(aNumber): Sets the image encoding quality (range is 0.0 - 1.0, 1.0 with being the highest).
slots.componentPlain(component):
Removes other components except specified from the image.
	Returns self.
slots.crop(x, y, width, height):
Crops the image to the specified values. Returns self.
	Raises an exception on error.
slots.error: Returns a String containing the current error or nil if there is no error.
slots.filterGauss(sigma): Returns new image as a result of applying filter. Implements Gauss smoothing filtering with parameter sigma.
slots.bounds(cutoff):
Returns an object continaing the bounds of the image. Cutoff is max bound color value for any color component.
	If it is negative, it is the min bound color value.
slots.linearContrast:
Performs contrast linarization. Per-pixel per-channel transformation that extends intensity to its full range.
	Returns self.
slots.componentCount: Returns the number of color components in the receiver as a Number.
slots.save(optionalPathString):
Sets the path to optionalPathString if provided and saves the image 
	in the format specified by the path extension. Returns self on success, nil on failure.
slots.removeAlpha: Removes the alpha component if the image contains one.  Returns self.
slots.isLA8: Returns true if the receiver is in LA8 (8bit Luminance-Alpha) format, false otherwise.
slots.flipX: Flips the image on the horizonal plane (left/right mirror). Returns self.
slots.isRGBA8: Returns true if the receiver is in RGBA8 format, false otherwise.
slots.histogram: Returns array with histogram values interleaved by channels.
slots.equalizeHistogram(mode):
Performs histogram equalization. Mode denotes quality factor and processing speed. Mode should be in range [0..3].
	Returns self.
slots.makeL8: Converts color model to Luminance 8bit (grayscale). Returns self.
slots.makeRGBA8: Converts color model to RGBA 8bit. Returns self.
slots.resizedTo(width, height):
Returns a new image of the receiver resized to the given width and height.
	Raises an exception on error.
slots.filterLinear(filterSizeX, filterSizeY, f: Returns new image as a result of applying filter.
slots.filterNonlinearGradients: Returns new image as a result of applying filter. Calculates abs(f'x) + abs(f'y).
slots.flipY: Flips the image on the vertical plane (top/bottom mirror). Returns self.
slots.filterWeightedMedian(filterSizeX, filter: Returns new image as a result of applying filter.
slots.data:
Returns a Buffer primitive containing the image data (loading it first if needed). 
	Manipulating this data will affect what is drawn when the receiver's draw method is called.
slots.baselineHeight:
Returns the pixel height (relative to the bottom of the image) which first contains a non-white pixel or -1 if
	no baseline is found.
slots.filterMin(filterSizeX, filterSizeY): Returns new image as a result of applying filter.
slots.bitPlain(component, bit):
Replaces contents with black-and-white image where white appears if and only if specified component contained 1 on the specified bit plain.
	Returns self.
slots.thresholdByGradient:
Performs thresholding. Threshold value is finded using Otsu's method.
	Returns self.
slots.isRGB8: Returns true if the receiver is in RGB8 format, false otherwise.
slots.setDataWidthHeightComponentCount(aSequen: Sets the image data and its parameters. Returns self.
slots.isL8: Returns true if the receiver is in L8 (8bit Luminance) format, false otherwise.
slots.setDecodingWidthHint(width): Sets the decoding width hint. Returns self.
slots.filterMax(filterSizeX, filterSizeY): Returns new image as a result of applying filter.
slots.setPath(aString): Sets the image path. Returns self.
slots.addAlpha: Adds an opaque alpha component if the image is in RGB format and does not already contain one.  Returns self.
slots.setDecodingHeightHint(width): Sets the decoding height hint. Returns self.
slots.filterMedian(filterSizeX, filterSizeY): Returns new image as a result of applying filter.
slots.filterUnsharpMask(a):
Returns new image as a result of applying filter. Implements unsharp mask filtering. 
	The result is sharpened image.
	The parameter value may by any but it makes sense if it is > 0.
slots.open(optionalPathString):
Sets the path to optionalPathString if provided and opens the image file. 
	Returns self on success, Nil on failure.
slots.resizedTo(newWidth, newHeight): Scales the image up to newWidth x newHeight.  Returns the newly scaled image.

Font.description:
The Font object can be used to load and render TypeTrype fonts. Example use; 
	
// within a GLUT display callback...

timesFont = Font clone open(\"times.ttf\")
if (timesFont error, write(\"Error loading font: \", timesFont error, \"\n\"); return)
timesFont setPointSize(16)
glColor(0,0,0,1)
timesFont draw(\"This is a test.\")
Rendering fonts using OpenGL textures

Smaller fonts (those having a point size around 30 or smaller, depending on the font) will automatically be cached in and rendered from a texture. This technique is very fast and should support rendering speeds as fast (or faster than) those of typical desktop font rendering systems. Larger font sizes(due to texture memory constraints) will be rendered to a pixelmap when displayed. Thanks to Mike Austin for implementing the font texturing system.

slots.widthOfString(aString):
Returns a Number with the width that aString would render 
	to with the receiver's current settings.
slots.stringIndexAtWidth(aString, startIndex,:
Returns the max index of the character in String (starting at startIndex) 
	that fits within width.
slots.error: Returns the current error string or nil if there is no error.
slots.setPixelSize(aNumber): Sets the size of the font in pixels. Returns self.
slots.drawString(aString, optionalStartIndex,:
Draws aString using the optional start and end indexes, if supplied. Returns self.

Note; Fonts are drawn as RGBA pixel maps. These blending options are recommended: 

	
glEnable(GL_BLEND)
glBlendFunc(GL_SRC_ALPHA, GL_ONE_MINUS_SRC_ALPHA)
slots.setPath(aString): Sets the Font path. Returns self.
slots.isTextured: Returns true if the font is being cached in and rendered from a texture, false otherwise.
slots.pixelHeight: Returns the height of the font measured in pixels.
slots.open(optionalPath): Opens the font. Sets path using optionalPath if supplied. Returns self.
slots.widthOfCharacter(aNumber): Returns the width of the character specified by aNumber in the receiver's font.

Box.description: A primitive for fast operations on rectangles.

slots.containsPoint(aPoint): Returns true if aPoint is within the receiver's bounds, false otherwise.
slots.setSize(aPoint): Copies the values in aPoint to the box's size point.
slots.print: Prints a string representation of the receiver to the standard output.
slots.origin: Returns the point object for the origin of the box.
slots.set(origin, size): Copies the values in origin and size to set the box's origin and size.
slots.setOrigin(aPoint): Copies the values in aPoint to the box's origin point.
slots.intersectsBox(aBox): Returns true if aBox is within the receiver's bounds, false otherwise.
slots.Union(aBox): Returns a new box containing the 2d union of the receiver and aBox.
slots.copy(aBox): Copies the values of aBox to the receiver.
slots.size: Returns the point object for the size of the box.

Box.description: A primitive for fast operations on rectangles.

slots.containsPoint(aPoint): Returns true if aPoint is within the receiver's bounds, false otherwise.
slots.setSize(aPoint): Copies the values in aPoint to the box's size point.
slots.print: Prints a string representation of the receiver to the standard output.
slots.origin: Returns the point object for the origin of the box.
slots.set(origin, size): Copies the values in origin and size to set the box's origin and size.
slots.setOrigin(aPoint): Copies the values in aPoint to the box's origin point.
slots.intersectsBox(aBox): Returns true if aBox is within the receiver's bounds, false otherwise.
slots.Union(aBox): Returns a new box containing the 2d union of the receiver and aBox.
slots.copy(aBox): Copies the values of aBox to the receiver.
slots.size: Returns the point object for the size of the box.

slots.gluScaleImage(formatIn, widthIn, heightI:
Scales the image data in dataSeqIn and outputs the result to dataSeqOut.
	Returns error code as a Number.

AsyncRequest.description:
Used for doing asynchronous file i/o. When this addon is loaded, it will override the File proto's readToBufferLength, readBufferOfLength and write methods to automatically use AsyncRequests.

Note: This addon is only needed for async file requests - all socket ops are already asynchronous in Io.

slots.isDone: Returns true if the request is done, false otherwise.
slots.setDescriptor(aDescriptorNumber): Sets the descriptor for the receiver. Returns self.
slots.descriptor: Returns the descriptor for the request.
slots.numberOfBytes: Returns the number of bytes associated with the request.
slots.copyBufferto(aSeq):
Copies the request buffer's data to aSeq.
	Returns nil on error or self otherwise.
slots.read(aSeq, numberOfBytes): Submits an async read request. Returns nil on error, self otherwise.
slots.error: Returns sequence containing the last error or nil otherwise.
slots.cancel: Cancels the request. Returns nil on error or self otherwise.
slots.position: Returns a Number for the position of the descriptor.
slots.write(fileOffset, aSeq, bufferOffset, nu: Submits an async write request. Returns nil on error, self otherwise.
slots.sync: Waits for the request to complete. Returns nil on error or self otherwise.

TagDB.description:
Binding for tagdb - a tagging database usefull for flickr-like tag searches.

Example use: 

tdb := TagDB clone

tdb setPath("test")
tdb open

writeln("size = ", tdb size)
tdb atKeyPutTags("f430 for sale", list("red", "ferrari"))
tdb atKeyPutTags("lotus esprit", list("lotus", "esprit"))
writeln("size = ", tdb size)
keys := tdb keysForTags(list("lotus"))
writeln("keys = ", tdb symbolForId(keys at(0)))
tdb close
tdb delete

slots.allUniqueTagIds: Returns a list of all unique tag ids.
slots.uniqueTagNames: Returns a list of all unique tag names.
slots.keysForTags(aTagNameList): Returns list of keys whose tags contain all of the tags in aTagNameList.
slots.symbolForId(aNumber): Returns the TagDB symbol for aNumber.
slots.atKeyPutTags(key, tagNameList): Sets the tags for key to those in tagNameList. Returns self.
slots.idForSymbol(aSeq): Returns the TagDB id Number for the symbol specified by aSeq.
slots.setPath(aPath): Sets the path to the tag database. Returns self.
slots.removeKey(aKey): Removes the specified key if it is present. Returns self.
slots.tagsAtKey(key): Returns the tags for the specified key.
slots.delete: Deletes all keys in the database.
slots.size: Returns number of keys in the database.
slots.keyAtIndex(indexNumber): Returns the key at the specified index of nil if the index is out of range.

DBI.description:
An object for wrapping libdbi to allow Io access to
a multitude of database systems transparently.

slots.version: Return string version of libdbi being used.
slots.drivers:
Get a list of drivers and its associated information:
  1. name
  2. description
  3. filename
  4. version
  5. date compiled
  6. maintainer
  7. url
slots.init: Initialize the DBI environment with the default driver path.
slots.initWithDriversPath: Initialize the DBI environment with the specified libdbi driver path.
slots.with(driverName): Get a new connection with the given driver.

DBIConn.description: An object that represents a DBI Connection.

slots.option(key): Retrieve an option value for the connection.
slots.optionClear(key): Clear a specific option associated with the connection.
slots.close: Close the connection to the database.
slots.execute(sql_query):
Perform a database query that expects no results. 
	Returns the number of rows affected.
slots.ping:
Ping the database to see if it's alive. 
	Will return true if it is, otherwise false.
slots.sequenceNext([name]): Return the next sequence that will be used during an INSERT query.
slots.queryOne([object], sql):
Perform a query and return the first
	result.

	If [object] is supplied, the object is populated with the contents of the
	result, the result is marked done and the object is returned.
slots.query(sql_query): Perform a database query returning a DBIResult object.
slots.sequenceLast([name]): Return the last inserted sequence value.
slots.optionPut(key,value): Add an option key, value pair to the connection.
slots.optionsClear: Clear all options associated with the connection
slots.quote(value): Quote a string value according to the database server's specifications.
slots.options: Retrieve an option list of the connection.

DBIRecord.description:
A DBI Record. When utilizing `foreach' or `populate' methods of a DBIResult object, you can pass an optional Object cloned from DBIRecord. This object will be populated with the row contents making it possible to write objects that represent your SQL results. A simple example would be: 
Person := DBIRecord clone do (fullName := method(firstName.." "..lastName))
q := conn query("SELECT id, firstName, lastName FROM people")
q foreach(Person, p, writeln("Name = ", p fullName))
As you can see, fullName was not in the SQL query, however, a dynamic method in your Person class. DBIRecord in and of itself provides no real functionality. It simply acts as an Object and stores the values from the SQL query into a Map. You can access the field information: 
o := r populate(Person)
o firstName            // would retrieve the firstName value of the SQL query
o setFirstName("John") // would update the object's firstName value to be John
Do not confuse the above example as updating the actual database. The call to setFirstName only updates the objects representation of firstName.

slots.with(aMap): Returns a new DBIRecord instance for the given value map.
slots.forward: Private method that implements getting and setting values.

DBIResult.description: A DBI Result created by a call to DBIConn query.

slots.at(index_or_name):
Returns the contents of the given field. 
	 The parameter can be a field index or a field name.
slots.last: Move the cursor to the last record.
slots.fields: Returns a list of field names in the result.
slots.next: Move the cursor to the next record.
slots.foreach([Object], value, message):
Loops over the records in the result starting at either the first result (if the cursor has never been moved) or its current location if moved. i.e. 
r := conn query("SELECT * FROM people")
r foreach(r, r at(1))
The above would start at the first row, however, you can move around in the result set and then foreach would pickup where you left off, for instance, say you wanted to skip the first three rows: 
r := conn query("SELECT * FROM people")
r seek(4)
r foreach(r, r at (1))
The above would start at the record #4, not at the beginning. The optional Object parameter would cause a decendent of DBIRecord to be populate instead of the index being set. This allows for advanced functionality. Please see `DBIRecord' for further information and an example.
slots.position: Return the current row's position (or index).
slots.seek(row_number): Move the cursor to the nth record.
slots.first: Move the cursor to the first record.
slots.populate(object):
Populates a decendent of DBIRecord with the current record's contents. 
	See `DBIRecord' for further explanation and an example.
slots.previous: Move the cursor to the previous record.
slots.size: Returns the number of rows available.
slots.done: Close and free the result. This must be called on each result. Failure to do so will cause memory leaks and open queries with the database server.

Obsidian.description: A double key/value database with cursors on first key. Basis for PDB.

slots.delete: Removes the persistence database file set via setPath.
slots.onAt: Return the value associated with slotName of stored object whose ppid is objId.

ObsidianServer.description:
A network interface for Obsidian.

Starting a Server

oServer := ObsidianServer clone
oServer localObject setName("foo") open
oServer start

Example Client Code

client := MDOConnection clone setHost("127.0.0.1") setPort(8000) connect
client onAtPut("1", "aKey", "aSlot")
client onAtPut("1", "cKey", "cSlot")
client onAtPut("1", "bKey", "bSlot")
client first("1", 5) println
a := client onAt("1", "aKey")
writeln("a = ", a)
b := client onAt("1", "bKey")
writeln("b = ", b)
client close
The messages accepted by the Obsidian server include: 
onAtPut(id, key, value)
onAt(id, key)
onRemoveAt(id, key)
onFirst(id, count)
onLast(id, count)
onAfter(id, key, count)
onBefore(id, key, count)

PMap.description:
PMap stores persistent data in a Map-like fashion and lazily loads
available slots from the PDB backing store. Values stored or loaded are cached
into local object slots.

slots.objectsForKeys:
Returns a list of values for each key in the list given. Keys beginning with an
underscore ("_") are returned verbatim.
slots.at(slotName):
Tries to obtain a value for slot slotName from a local slot of that name, or tries to load it from the PDB if the local slot does not exist. When all else fails, returns nil.

If slotName begins with an underscore ("_"), returns the id of the slot from PDB instead of the value.
slots.init: Initialize a new PMap and automatically add it as a persistent object to PDB.
slots.persistSlots: Cleans up dirty slots by committing them to PDB.
slots.shouldPersistByDefault:
PDB boolean flag indicating whether this object should be considered for persistence
when persistence has not been specifically requested by calling ppid() or PDB addObjectToPersist.
Always true by default for PMap.
slots.atPut(slotName, value): Records value in the slot named slotName.
slots.slotCount: Returns the number of slots committed to PDB.
slots.persist: Commits the PMap's slots to PDB.
slots.createIfAbsent: Creates a slot with a new PMap clone if not already present.

slots.objectAtPpid: Return the object associated in the database with a ppid.
slots.sync:
Immediately persist data for all objects marked dirty by Collector whose 
shouldPersistByDefault is true, or that have specifically requested to be
persisted since the last sync via addObjectToPersist.
slots.addObjectToPersist: Register an object to be persisted in the next PDB sync.
slots.root: Return the root PMap object used to store and retrieve persistent objects and their slots.
slots.show: Print to standard output a listing of all objects and IDs stored in PDB.
slots.collectGarbage: Remove from PDB all objects not accessible via the root object.
slots.reopen: Sync, close and reopen the PDB store.
slots.newId: Generate a new PDB id number for use as a persistent object's ppid.

PDB.description:
An arbitrary graph database with support for on-disk garbage collection. Example use:

Setup

PDB open
PDB root atPut("users", PMap clone)
PDB sync
PDB close
PMap is a Map/Dictionary whose keys are lazily loaded from the database. PDB root is the root PMap in the database and the root object used for PDB's garbage collector. PDB sync needs to be called to write any changes to the database.

Defining a Persistent Object

User := Object clone pSlots(name, email)
The pSlots(), declares which slots on the object should be persisted. The List, Date, Sequence and Number primitives already know how to persist themselves.

Inserting a Persistent Object

PDB open 
user := User clone setName("steve") setEmail("steve@foo.com")
PDB root users atPut("steve", user)
PDB sync
PDB close

Accessing a Persistent Object

user := PDB root users at("steve")
writeln("user name = ", user name, " email = ", user email)

Updating a Persistent Object

user setEmail("steve@newDomain.com")
PDB sync
PDB sync will scan all persistent objects in the vm and save any with changes to their persistent slots. If the object was already in the database, only its updated slots will be written.

Removing an entry in a PMap

PDB root users removeAt("steve")

Removing a persistent object

This is never done explicitly, instead calling: 
PDB collectGarbage
Will remove all objects unreachable by the reference graph from the root PMap.

Notes: Currently, PDB is a singleton.

Memcached.description: memcached is a high-performance, distributed memory object caching system, generic in nature, but intended for use in speeding up dynamic web applications by alleviating database load. Memcached is an Io client library for memcached, based on C libmemcached.

slots.flushAll([expiration]):
Asks memcached to invalidate all existing items immediately (by default)
or after the expiration specified.
Always returns true.
slots.set(key, value[, expiration]):
Asks memcached to store the value identified by the key.
Returns true on success, otherwise raises an exception.
slots.atIfAbsentPut(key, value[, expiration]):
If a value is present at the specified key, its value is returned.
	Otherwise, inserts the new value and returns it.
slots.delete(key[, time]):
Asks memcached to delete an item with the given key.
time is the amount of time in seconds (or Unix time until which)
the client wishes the server to refuse "add" and "replace" commands
with this key.
Returns true on success, false if there is no item with the given key.
Otherwise raises an exception.
slots.get(key):
Asks memcached to retrieve data corresponding to the key.
Raises "NOT FOUND" if the data is not there.
slots.atPut(key, value[, expiration]):
Asks memcached to store the value identified by the key.
	Same as Memcached set, but returns self.
slots.removeAt(key): Asks memcached to remove value with a given key. Returns self.
slots.decr([offset]):
Asks memcached to decrement data for some item in place. The data for the item is
treated as decimal representation of a 64-bit unsigned integer. If the
current data value does not conform to such a representation, the
commands behave as if the value were 0.
Default offset is 1.
Returns the new value.
slots.prepend(key, value):
Asks memcached to add this value to an existing key before existing value.
Returns true on success, otherwise raises an exception.
value should be a Sequence.
Supported by memcached 1.2.4+
slots.incr([offset]):
Asks memcached to increment data for some item in place. The data for the item is
treated as decimal representation of a 64-bit unsigned integer. If the
current data value does not conform to such a representation, the
commands behave as if the value were 0.
Default offset is 1.
Returns the new value.
slots.getMulti(keys):
Asks memcached to retrieve data corresponding to the list of keys.
Returns a Map with the results.
If some of the keys appearing in a retrieval request are not sent back
by the server in the item list this means that the server does not
hold items with such keys
slots.replace(key, value[, expiration]):
Asks memcached to store the value identified by the key,
but only if the server *does* already hold data for this key.
Returns true on success, false if there is already data for this key.
Otherwise raises an exception.
slots.at(key, optionalDefaultValue):
Asks memcached to retrieve data corresponding to the key.
	Returns nil if the data is not there (or if the data *is* nil).
slots.append(key, value):
Asks memcached to add this value to an existing key after existing value.
Returns true on success, otherwise raises an exception.
value should be a Sequence.
Supported by memcached 1.2.4+
slots.stats:
Returns a Map with servers' statistics. Keys are server addresses,
values are maps with actual stats.
slots.with(servers):
Returns a new instance of Memcached.
	Accepts a Sequence or a List of server addresses.
slots.add(key, value[, expiration]):
Asks memcached to store the value identified by the key,
but only if the server *doesn't* already hold data for this key.
Returns true on success, false in case of a collision.
Otherwise raises an exception.
slots.addServer(address):
Adds a memcached server. address is a "host:port" string, e.g., "127.0.0.1:11211"
Returns self.

QDBM.description: An ordered key/value database that supports transactions and arbitrary kay and value sizes.

slots.cursorKey: Returns current cursor key or nil.
slots.cursorRemove: Removes the current cursor postion. Returns self.
slots.cursorJumpBackward(key): Move cursor to previous record around key. Returns self
slots.cursorFirst: Move cursor to first record. Returns self
slots.cursorPut(value): Sets the value at the current cursor postion. Returns self.
slots.size: Returns number of records in database. Returns self
slots.sizeAt(keySymbol): Returns the size of the value at the given key or nil if there is no such key.
slots.cursorJumpForward(key): Move cursor to next record around key. Returns self
slots.cursorLast: Move cursor to last record. Returns self
slots.atPut(keySymbol, valueSequence): Sets the value of valueSequence with the key keySymbol. Returns self.
slots.name: Returns the name of the database.
slots.cursorValue: Returns current cursor value or nil.
slots.cursorPrevious:
Move cursor to previous record. Returns true if there is another key, 
	or false if there is no previous record.
slots.atRemove(keySymbol): Removes the specified key. Returns self
slots.cursorNext:
Move cursor to next record. Returns true if there is another key, 
	or false if there is no next record.
slots.at(keySymbol): Returns a Sequence for the value at the given key or nil if there is no such key.

SQLite.description:
SQLite provides a embedded simple and fast (2x faster than PostgreSQL or MySQL) SQL database. See http://www.hwaci.com/sw/sqlite/ for details. It's SQL command set is described at http://www.hwaci.com/sw/sqlite/lang.html. SQLite was written by Dr. Richard Hipp who offers consulting services for custom modifications and support of SQLite. Example: 
	
db := SQLite clone
db setPath("myDatabase.sqlite")
db open
db exec("CREATE TABLE Dbm (key, value)")
db exec("CREATE INDEX DbmIndex ON Dbm (key)")
db exec("INSERT INTO Dbm ('key', 'value') VALUES ('a', '123')")
db exec("INSERT INTO Dbm ('key', 'value') VALUES ('a', 'efg')")
rows := db exec("SELECT key, value FROM Dbm WHERE key='a'")
db exec("DELETE FROM Dbm WHERE key='a'")
rows := db exec("SELECT key, value FROM Dbm WHERE key='a'")
db close

slots.columnNamesOfTable(tableName): Returns a list containing the names of all columns in the specified table.
slots.error:
Results a string containing the current error. 
	If there is no error, Nil is returned.
slots.escapeString(aString):
Returns a translated version of aString by making two 
	copies of every single-quote (') character. This has the effect 
	of escaping the end-of-string meaning of single-quote within a string literal.
slots.close:
Closes the database if it is open. Returns self. 
	If the database is open when the open is garbage collected, 
	it will be automatically closed.
slots.path: Returns the path to the database file.
slots.setPath(aSeq): Sets the path to the database file. Returns self.
slots.timeoutSeconds:
Returns the number of seconds to wait before timing out an open call. 
	If the number is 0, an open call will never timeout.
slots.exec(aString):
Opens the database if it is not already open and executes
	aString as an sql command. Results a List of Map objects or Nil if
	there was an error. Each map holds the contents of a row.
	The key/value pairs of the maps being column name/column value
	pairs for a row. ")
slots.changes:
Returns the number of rows that were changed by the most 
	recent SQL statement. Or Nil if the database is closed.
slots.viewNames: Returns a list containing the names of all views in the database.

SQLite3.description:
SQLite provides a embedded simple and fast (2x faster than PostgreSQL or MySQL) SQL database. See http://www.hwaci.com/sw/sqlite/ for details. It's SQL command set is described at http://www.hwaci.com/sw/sqlite/lang.html. SQLite was written by Dr. Richard Hipp who offers consulting services for custom modifications and support of SQLite. Example: 

	
db := SQLite clone
db setPath("myDatabase.sqlite")
db open
db exec("CREATE TABLE Dbm (key, value)")
db exec("CREATE INDEX DbmIndex ON Dbm (key)")
db exec("INSERT INTO Dbm ('key', 'value') VALUES ('a', '123')")
db exec("INSERT INTO Dbm ('key', 'value') VALUES ('a', 'efg')")
rows := db exec("SELECT key, value FROM Dbm WHERE key='a'")
db exec("DELETE FROM Dbm WHERE key='a'")
rows := db exec("SELECT key, value FROM Dbm WHERE key='a'")
db close

Syslog.description:
Provides access to a Unix system's system logger. 

logger = Syslog clone do(
	identity("SyslogTest")
	facility(facilityMap at("LOG_USER"))
	options(List append(optionsMap at("LOG_PID"), optionsMap at("LOG_CONS")))
	priority(priorityMap at("LOG_INFO"))
	open(facility, options)
	mask(List append(maskMap at("LOG_PRIMASK")))
	log(priority, "*** Merely a test ***")
	close
)

Note: This is partially tested. Please let me know of any problems you happen to stumble across, or if it could be better. --Jeremy Tregunna

slots.reopen(aFacility, someOptions, optionalI:
Reopens an already open log session. This is useful if you wish to 
	change the facility you are logging to, the options you are logging 
	with, or the identity of the session. Takes the same options as the open slot.
slots.options(optionalOptions):
If optionalOptions is specified, it should represent a list of the logging 
	options you can find in the optionsMap slot. All the values in the supplied 
	aList will be OR'd together when you call the open or reopen slots. 
	Returns the list of options if optionalFacility is omitted.
slots.identity(optionalIdentity): If optionalIdentity is specified, provides an identity for all of the messages you will be sending to the syslog daemon. Returns the identity.
slots.close: Closes a log that has previously been opened for writing.
slots.mask(optionalMask):
If optionalMask is specified, optionalMask is a list which contains 
	any one or more values stored in the maskMap hash that will be OR'd 
	together, to provide the proper mask. Returns the logging mask (as a List).
slots.open(aPriority, someOptions, optionalIde:
Opens the syslog for writing. optionalIdentity need not be entered 
	and will default to the name of the distribution of Io you are running 
	or if you have embedded Io into your application and set 
	Lobby distribution = "foo", it will be set to "foo".
slots.maskMap:
Contains keys/value pairs which represent numbers that specify the logging mask. These values may be any one (or more) of the following:

  • LOG_PRIMASK
  • LOG_FACMASK
slots.facility(optionalFacility):
Specifies the logging facility, which can be one of any of the values 
	found in the facilityMap map. If optionalFacility is omitted, returns 
	the currently set facility.
slots.optionsMap:
A map containing key/value pairs holding all available options. These include:

  • LOG_PID
  • LOG_CONS
  • LOG_ODELAY
  • LOG_NDELAY
  • LOG_NOWAIT
  • LOG_PERROR
slots.facilityMap:
Contains the following keys, which represent numbers that can be used when opening a log:

  • LOG_KERN
  • LOG_USER
  • LOG_MAIL
  • LOG_DAEMON
  • LOG_AUTH
  • LOG_SYSLOG
  • LOG_LPR
  • LOG_NEWS
  • LOG_UUCP
  • LOG_CRON
  • LOG_AUTHPRIV
  • LOG_FTP
  • LOG_RESERVED0
  • LOG_RESERVED1
  • LOG_RESERVED2
  • LOG_RESERVED3
  • LOG_LOCAL0
  • LOG_LOCAL1
  • LOG_LOCAL2
  • LOG_LOCAL3
  • LOG_LOCAL4
  • LOG_LOCAL5
  • LOG_LOCAL6
  • LOG_LOCAL7
slots.priority(optionalPriority):
If optionalPriority is specified, sets the value, and returns it. 
	If no value is specified, will return the previously stored value if 
	one has been set previously.
slots.priorityMap:
Contains key/value pairs for logging priorities for use when calling the log() method. These include:

  • LOG_EMERG
  • LOG_ALERT
  • LOG_CRIT
  • LOG_ERR
  • LOG_WARNING
  • LOG_NOTICE
  • LOG_INFO
  • LOG_DEBUG
slots.isOpen: Returns self if the log is opened for writing. Otherwise, returns Nil.
slots.log:
Writes the supplied data to the log. Requires 2 arguments:

  • Logging Priority
  • Message to log

Curses.description:
Curses allows writing and reading at arbitrary positions on the terminal. You have to call init to set the terminal to curses mode and end to end curses mode. The terminal is not updated until refresh is called. It is a bad idea to use the standard io's read and write methods when the terminal is in curses mode. The Curses primitive was written by Edwin Zacharias.

Here's an example that prints Hello at column 5 and row 7; 

Curses init
Curses move(5, 7) print(\"Hello\")
Curses refresh
Curses end

Beanstalk.credits: Aleksey Yeschenko, 2009. Default arguments and some other things taken from beanstalk-client-ruby by Keith Rarick.
Beanstalk.description:
beanstalkd is a fast, distributed, in-memory workqueue service. See http://xph.us/software/beanstalkd/
An example from http://xph.us/software/beanstalkd/:
First, have one process put a job into the queue: 
producer := Beanstalk clone connect("127.0.0.1:11300")
producer put("hello")
Then start another process to take jobs out of the queue and run them: 
worker := Beanstalk clone connect("127.0.0.1:11300")
loop(
	job := worker reserve
	job body println # prints "hello"
	job delete
)
See Beanstalk.io code and protocol description (http://github.com/kr/beanstalkd/tree/master/doc/protocol.txt) for details. Both are short and easy to read.
Stat commands depend on YAML.

slots.bury(id, pri): Puts a job into the "buried" state
slots.connect(address): Connects to a beanstalk server. address is a "host:port" string, e.g., "127.0.0.1:11300"
slots.touch(id): Allows a worker to request more time to work on a job.
slots.release(id): Puts a reserved job back into the ready queue
slots.put(body, pri, delay, ttr):
Inserts a job into the queue.
pri - priority, an integer < 2**32. Jobs with smaller priority values will be scheduled before jobs with larger priorities. The most urgent priority is 0; the least urgent priority is 4294967295.
delay - an integer number of seconds to wait before putting the job in the ready queue. The job will be in the "delayed" state during this time.
ttr - time to run, an integer number of seconds to allow a worker to run this job.
slots.delete(id): Removes a job with a given id from the server, entirely
slots.reserve(timeout): Returns and reserves a job (waits until one becomes available if necessary)

	return List clone append(1)

MDOServer.description:
A Minimal Distributed Objects server. Example; 
DateServer := Object clone do(
	acceptedMessageNames := list("currentDate")
	currentDate := method(Date clone asNumber)
)

mdoServer := MDOServer clone 
mdoServer setHost("127.0.0.1")  setPort(8123) 
mdoServer setLocalObject(DateServer clone)
mdoServer start

MDOConnection.description:
A Minimal Distributed Objects connection. Example; 
dateServerCon := MDOConnection clone setHost("127.0.0.1") setPort(8123) connect
writeln("date from date server: ", Date fromNumber(dateServerCon currentDate))
dateServerCon close
See the docs for MDOServer for the DateServer code.

A MDOConnection will pause calling coroutines until the response is received. Mutliple requests can be sent before a single request returns if they are sent from separate coroutines.

DOConnection.description:
The DOConnection object is useful for communicating with remote servers in a way that makes it look just like the sending of local messages. Proxies are automatically created on either side for passed objects, with the exception of strings and numbers, which are passed by value. Example: 
con := DOConnection clone setHost("127.0.0.1") setPort(8456) connect
result := con serverObject test(1)
writeln(result)
r := result at(0)
writeln(r)
r := result at(1)
writeln(r)
Implementation Notes:

The format of the Distributed Objects message is a list of NullCharacter terminated strings in one of these two formats:

Send message format: 

s NullCharacter targetId NullCharacter messageName NullCharacter argCount NullCharacter argType NullCharacter argValue NullCharacter (next arg type and value, etc)
Reply message format: 
r NullCharacter argType NullCharacter argvalue NullCharacter
If the argument is not a String, Number or nil then: If it is local to the sender, the type is RemoteObject. If it is a proxy to a remote object, the type is LocalObject. This isn't optimized yet.

slots.setPort(portNumber): Sets the port number to connect to. Returns self.
slots.setHost(ipString): Sets the host ip to connect to. Returns self or an Error, if one occurs.
slots.serverObject: A handle to the remote DOServer's root object. Returns result from server or an Error, if one occurs.
slots.close: Close the connection, if it is open. Returns self.
slots.connect: Connect to the remote DOServer. Returns self or an Error, if one occurs.

GoogleSearch.description:
Object for performing web searches via Google. Example: 
GoogleSearch clone setSearchTerm("iolanguage") find links foreach(println)
while(Coroutine yieldingCoros size > 1, yield)

slots.links: Returns the list of link results.
slots.maxPages: Returns the max number of pages to fetch results from.
slots.setMaxPages(aNumber): Sets the max number of pages to fetch results from. Returns self.

GooglePage.description: Object representing one page of search results.

slots.links: Returns the list of link results.
slots.pageNumber: Returns the current page number of results.
slots.setSearchTerm(aSeq): Sets the search term. Returns self.

CGI.description:
CGI supports accessing CGI parameters passed in environment variables or standard input by a web servers like Apache. Example use: 
#!./ioServer

cgi = CGI clone

redirect = cgi getParameters at("redirurl")
if (redirect and redirect != "",
	redirect clipAfterStartOfSeq("\r")
	redirect clipAfterStartOfSeq("\n")
	cgi redirect(redirect)
	System exit(0)
 )

cgi header("Content-type", "text/html")

cgi write("<html><head><title>test</title><body>")
cgi write("GET Parameters:")
cgi getParameters foreach(k, v,
	cgi write(k .. " = " .. v .. ","))
)

cgi write("POST Parameters:")
cgi postParameters foreach(k, v,
	cgi write(k .. " = " .. v .. ","))
)

cgi write("COOKIES:")
cgi cookies foreach(k, v,
	cgi write(k .. " = " .. v .. ",")
)

slots.requestParameter(name): Lazy developer's helper funtion. Retrieves a value from GET or POST, POST first
slots.redirect(url): Send a location: and redirect the user.  May only be called before write() is called.  It is left to the caller to stop any further processing.
slots.cookies: Returns a Map of cookies provided by the client
slots.getParameters: Parses the QUERY_STRING environment variable and returns a Map containing key/value query value pairs.  For testing, a QUERY_STRING can be passed to standard in, one line will be read
slots.encodeUrlParam(aString): Returns a URL encoded version of aString.
slots.isInWebScript: Checks to see if this is being called within a CGI request or from the command-line (testing).  Simply checks for System getEnvironmentVariable("GATEWAY_INTERFACE")
slots.setCookie(name, value, expiresDate, doma:
Sets a cookie, keep in mind this will not be available in cookies() until they next visit to the site.  
	Parameters other than name and value are optional.
slots.remoteHost: REMOTE_HOST from web server - User's host (often blank)
slots.maxPostSizeExceeded: Returns true if the POST data exceeds a set maxPostSize
slots.postData: The raw post data sent to the script.  Only set if getEnvironmentVariable("REQUEST_METHOD") asLowercase == "post".
slots.maxPostSize: Maximum size in bytes, to process from user submitted data.  Data greater than this will result in a nil postData slot
slots.httpHeader(name): Fetch a header supplied by the client, such as 'referer'
slots.header(name, value, sendMultiple):
Add a header to the output, may only be called before write() is called.  
	One of each header will be sent unless sendMultiple is true
slots.remoteAddress: REMOTE_ADDR from web server - User's IP
slots.contentLength: CONTENT_LENGTH from web server - Size of POST Data
slots.postParameters:
Parses the POST data, multipart and urlencoded. Returns a map of submitted variables. For uploaded files, an Object is returned with these slots: 
fileName
content (raw content of file as Sequence)
contentType
contentEncoding
size (in characters/bytes)
asString (pretty string of name, type, size)
slots.status(statusCode):
Numeric status code to send to the client.  
	Normally, the server will figure this out on its own, but this allows handling 404s and such.
slots.write(string, [string...]): Send content for the body of the response
slots.decodeUrlParam(aString): Returns a URL decoded version of aString.

HCResponseParser.description: Handles parsing response received during an HCConnection

HCRequest.description: State describing an HTTP request to be sent by an HCConnection

slots.headerAt(name): Returns the value for header with name
